code: library(devtools) install_github("doomlab/ViSe") library(ViSe) library(cowplot) library(ggplot2) library(plotly) #>  #> Attaching package: 'plotly' #> The following object is masked from 'package:ggplot2': #>  #>     last_plot #> The following object is masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter #> The following object is masked from 'package:graphics': #>  #>     layout

title: Package Functions
text: demonstrate use visual sensitivity analysis, use effect child maltreatment extent mental health problems terms internalising externalising behaviour. study Kisely colleagues (Kisely et al., 2018) based general population sample Brisbane, Australia, compared 3554 mother-child pairs without ‘substantiated child maltreatment’ , example, 73 pairs child neglect. Note results vary across different types maltreatment assessed, choose child neglect results (smaller still considerable l adjustment) particularly suited illustrating sensitivity analysis. Maltreatment assessed ‘linkage state child protection agency data’. Internalising externalising behaviours measured using Youth Self-Report (YSR) scale (Achenbach & Rescorla, 2001) around age 21. study reports unadjusted mean differences mean differences adjusted ‘gender, parental ethnicity, maternal age, family income, maternal relationship status, maternal education, youth income level, youth education level, youth marital status’ (e.g., likely based ordinary least squares regression, paper specify). See supplemental document https://static.cambridge.org/content/id/urn:cambridge.org:id:article:S0007125018002076/resource/name/S0007125018002076sup001.docx

title: Package Functions
text: obtain estimates two-tailed 95% confidence intervals effect size d scale (via d = MdifferenceM_{difference} / SDTotalSD_{Total}, similar Glass’ Δ\Delta), divided reported unadjusted adjusted mean differences internalising externalising respective standard deviations total sample.
code: internal_unadjusted <- list(   mean_diff = 3.68,   lower_diff = 1.73,   upper_diff = 5.62,   sd = 8.29 )  internal_adjusted <- list(   mean_diff = 2.73,   lower_diff = 0.77,   upper_diff = 4.69,   sd = 8.28 )  external_unadjusted <- list(   mean_diff = 3.72,   lower_diff = 2.13,   upper_diff = 5.32,   sd = 6.81 )  external_adjusted <- list(   mean_diff = 3.10,   lower_diff = 1.49,   upper_diff = 4.71,   sd = 6.81 )  list_values <- list(internal_unadjusted, internal_adjusted,                   external_unadjusted, external_adjusted) list_names <- c("internal_unadjusted", "internal_adjusted",                   "external_unadjusted", "external_adjusted") names(list_values) <- list_names  for (i in list_names){   list_values[[i]][["d"]] <- list_values[[i]][["mean_diff"]] / list_values[[i]][["sd"]]   list_values[[i]][["lower_d"]] <- list_values[[i]][["lower_diff"]] / list_values[[i]][["sd"]]   list_values[[i]][["upper_d"]] <- list_values[[i]][["upper_diff"]] / list_values[[i]][["sd"]] }  unlist(list_values) #>  internal_unadjusted.mean_diff internal_unadjusted.lower_diff  #>                     3.68000000                     1.73000000  #> internal_unadjusted.upper_diff         internal_unadjusted.sd  #>                     5.62000000                     8.29000000  #>          internal_unadjusted.d    internal_unadjusted.lower_d  #>                     0.44390832                     0.20868516  #>    internal_unadjusted.upper_d    internal_adjusted.mean_diff  #>                     0.67792521                     2.73000000  #>   internal_adjusted.lower_diff   internal_adjusted.upper_diff  #>                     0.77000000                     4.69000000  #>           internal_adjusted.sd            internal_adjusted.d  #>                     8.28000000                     0.32971014  #>      internal_adjusted.lower_d      internal_adjusted.upper_d  #>                     0.09299517                     0.56642512  #>  external_unadjusted.mean_diff external_unadjusted.lower_diff  #>                     3.72000000                     2.13000000  #> external_unadjusted.upper_diff         external_unadjusted.sd  #>                     5.32000000                     6.81000000  #>          external_unadjusted.d    external_unadjusted.lower_d  #>                     0.54625551                     0.31277533  #>    external_unadjusted.upper_d    external_adjusted.mean_diff  #>                     0.78120411                     3.10000000  #>   external_adjusted.lower_diff   external_adjusted.upper_diff  #>                     1.49000000                     4.71000000  #>           external_adjusted.sd            external_adjusted.d  #>                     6.81000000                     0.45521292  #>      external_adjusted.lower_d      external_adjusted.upper_d  #>                     0.21879589                     0.69162996

title: Package Functions
text: visualise lower level confidence interval l, must obtain lower bound confidence interval proposed effect size. ViSe includes function calculate_d() calculates t.test() output, dataframes, individual vectors data, sample statistics (M, SD, n group), t-test values, pre-calculated d-value. example, d value original research, along sample sizes study can used calculate two-tailed dlow_central one-tailed done_low_central lower confidence interval. package vignette shows possible ways calculate values data includes non-centralized confidence intervals effect size d well ().
code: internal_unadj_output <- calculate_d(   d = list_values$internal_adjusted$d, # d value   a = .05, # alpha for confidence interval   lower = TRUE, # you expect d to be positive    n1 = 71, # sample size group 1    n2 = 3653  # sample size group 2 )  internal_unadj_output$dlow_central #> [1] 0.09465985 internal_unadj_output$done_low_central #> [1] 0.1324648  # note, the program also provide noncentral t confidence intervals # in this case, they are unusable because d has been calculated from  # mean difference / control rather than mean difference / spooled # therefore the approximation of t and the noncentral  # limits is not appropriate

title: Package Functions
Package Functions
text: research studies use d effect size interest, ViSe provides functionality convert effect sizes. other_to_d() function can used convert effect sizes f, f2f^2, NNT, r, probability superiority, U1, U2, U3, proportional overlap d. options other_to_d(): effect size d value can used visualize effects conversions visualize_effects() function. can use percent, color, font family options adjust resulting graph readability color scheme.   package uses following conversion functions can implemented separately well:
code: other_to_d(nnt = 35) #> [1] 0.051 f = NULL, f2 = NULL, nnt = NULL, r = NULL, prob = NULL, prop_u1 = NULL, prop_u2 = NULL, prop_u3 = NULL, prop_overlap = NULL visualize_effects(d = list_values$internal_adjusted$d,                   circle_color = "lightblue",                   circle_fill = "gray",                   percent_color = "darkblue",                   percent_size = 10,                   text_color = "black",                    font_family = "Times") #> $graph # note graphs look better scaled, try saving them  # ggsave(filename = "visualize_effects.png")  # you can make very ugly graphs if you want visualize_effects(d = .2,                    circle_color = "green",                    circle_fill = "orange",                    percent_color = "pink",                    percent_size = 20,                    text_color = "purple",                   font_family = "Arial") #> $graph d_to_r(d = list_values$internal_adjusted$d) #> [1] 0.1626596 d_to_f2(d = list_values$internal_adjusted$d) #> $f #> [1] 0.1648551 #>  #> $f2 #> [1] 0.02717719 d_to_nnt(d = list_values$internal_adjusted$d) #> [1] 5.424537 probability_superiority(d = list_values$internal_adjusted$d) #> [1] 0.5921738 proportion_overlap(d = list_values$internal_adjusted$d) #> $u1 #> [1] 0.2315626 #>  #> $u2 #> [1] 0.565471 #>  #> $u3 #> [1] 0.6291905 #>  #> $p_o #> [1] 0.8690581

what: Visualization of sensitivity of effect size to bias
title: Package Functions
text: Now idea d value, lower confidence limit l, potential effect sizes, can create sensitivity plot effect size bias. visualize different d values representation distribution overlap, use estimate_d() examine different effect sizes:  Similarly, estimate_r() shows scatterplot entered correlation coefficient visualize relation two variables:  can use two estimation functions create graph shows combinations effect size r indicate causal effect. can enter effect size conversion options, converted d labels inspection. shaded area represents area considered effect, points represent entered combination r effect size. Points shaded area considered sensitive bias. can use plotly library hover dots see values (also embedded shiny app). Note: run make package CRAN compatible (plotly makes html files large).  options graph, including defaults:
code: estimate_d(d = .09,             fill_1 = "red",             fill_2 = "blue",             text_color = "black")$graph estimate_r(r = .30)$graph visual_c_mapped <-   # your lower confidence limit required   visualize_c_map(dlow = list_values$internal_adjusted$lower_d,                    # correlation values required                   r_values = c(.1, .4, .3),                   # other effect sizes you want to plot                   d_values = c(.2, .8),                   nnt_values = c(60),                   # if you think d will be positive                    lower = TRUE,                   # as many values as the max number effects                   point_colors = c("red", "green", "blue"),                   # a size for the shapes                   size = 2,                   # shape 1                   shape_1 = 2,                   # shape 2, make these the same number if you                    # want the shapes overlapping                   # we think two different ones helps readability                    shape_2 = 3,                   # color of the background highlighted area                    ribbon_color = "lightblue"                   )  visual_c_mapped$graph ggsave(filename = "visualize_c_map.png", width = 8,         height = 6, dpi = 300)  # ggplotly(visual_c_mapped$graph) visualize_c_map(   dlow,   r_values,   d_values = NULL,   f_values = NULL,   f2_values = NULL,   nnt_values = NULL,   prob_values = NULL,   prop_u1_values = NULL,   prop_u2_values = NULL,   prop_u3_values = NULL,   prop_overlap_values = NULL,   lower = TRUE,   point_colors = c("red", "green", "blue"),   size = 2,   shape_1 = 2,   shape_2 = 3,   ribbon_color = "lightblue" )

what: \(d_s\) for Between Subjects with Pooled SD Denominator — calculate_d
title: \(d_s\) for Between Subjects with Pooled SD Denominator — calculate_d
text: function displays d two subjects groups gives central non-central confidence interval using pooled standard deviation denominator.

title: \(d_s\) for Between Subjects with Pooled SD Denominator — calculate_d
code: calculate_d(   m1 = NULL,   m2 = NULL,   sd1 = NULL,   sd2 = NULL,   n1 = NULL,   n2 = NULL,   t = NULL,   model = NULL,   df = NULL,   x_col = NULL,   y_col = NULL,   d = NULL,   a = 0.05,   lower = TRUE )

title: \(d_s\) for Between Subjects with Pooled SD Denominator — calculate_d
text: m1 mean group one m2 mean group two sd1 standard deviation group one sd2 standard deviation group two n1 sample size group one n2 sample size group two t optional, calculate d independent t, must include n1 n2 degrees freedom model optional, calculate d t.test independent t, must still include n1 n2 df optional dataframe includes x_col y_col x_col name column contains factor levels numeric vector group 1 scores y_col name column contains dependent score numeric vector group 2 scores d previously calculated d value study significance level lower Use indicate want lower upper bound d one sided confidence intervals. d positive, generally want lower = TRUE, negative d values enter lower = FALSE upper bound closer zero.

title: \(d_s\) for Between Subjects with Pooled SD Denominator — calculate_d
text: Provides effect size (Cohen's *d*) associated central non-central confidence intervals, *t*-statistic, confidence intervals associated means group, well standard deviations standard errors means group. one-tailed confidence interval also included sensitivity analyses. d effect size dlow noncentral lower level confidence interval d value dhigh noncentral upper level confidence interval d value dlow_central central lower level confidence interval d value dhigh_central central upper level confidence interval d value done_low noncentral lower bound one tailed confidence interval done_low_central central lower bound one tailed confidence interval M1 mean group one sd1 standard deviation group one mean se1 standard error group one mean M1low lower level confidence interval group one mean M1high upper level confidence interval group one mean M2 mean group two sd2 standard deviation group two mean se2 standard error group two mean M2low lower level confidence interval group two mean M2high upper level confidence interval group two mean spooled pooled standard deviation sepooled pooled standard error n1 sample size group one n2 sample size group two df degrees freedom (n1 - 1 + n2 - 1) t t-statistic p p-value estimate d statistic confidence interval APA style markdown printing statistic t-statistic APA style markdown printing

title: \(d_s\) for Between Subjects with Pooled SD Denominator — calculate_d
text: calculate \(d_s\), mean two subtracted mean one divided pooled standard deviation. $$d_s = \frac{M_1 - M_2}{S_{pooled}}$$ provide one combination following: 1: m1 n2 2: t, n1, n2 3: model, n1, n2 4: df, "x_col", "y_col" 5: x_col, y_col numeric vectors 6: d, n1, n2 must provide alpha lower ensure right confidence interval provided .

title: \(d_s\) for Between Subjects with Pooled SD Denominator — calculate_d

title: Convert d to Number Needed to Treat — d_to_nnt
text: Kraemer H.C., Kupfer D.J. (2006) Size treatment effects importance clinical research practice. Biolological Psychiatry, 59, 990–996. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.biopsych.2005.09.014

what: Convert other statistics to d — other_to_d
title: Convert other statistics to d — other_to_d
text: function allows convert effect sizes d including f, f squared, number needed treat, correlation coefficient, probability superiority, proportion overlap (u1, u2, u3, proportion distribution overlap). Please note approximations.

title: Convert other statistics to d — other_to_d
code: other_to_d(   f = NULL,   f2 = NULL,   nnt = NULL,   r = NULL,   prob = NULL,   prop_u1 = NULL,   prop_u2 = NULL,   prop_u3 = NULL,   prop_overlap = NULL )

title: Convert other statistics to d — other_to_d
text: f Cohen's f f2 Cohen's f squared nnt Number needed treat r Correlation coefficient prob Probability superiority prop_u1 Proportion Overlap U1 prop_u2 Proportion Overlap U2 prop_u3 Proportion Overlap U3 prop_overlap Proportion Overlap Distributions

title: Convert other statistics to d — other_to_d
text: d effect size

Probability of Superiority Calculation — probability_superiority
text: function calculates probability superiority independent samples Cohen's d calculation.

title: Probability of Superiority Calculation — probability_superiority
code: probability_superiority(   d = NULL,   m1 = NULL,   m2 = NULL,   sd1 = NULL,   sd2 = NULL,   n1 = NULL,   n2 = NULL,   a = 0.05,   t = NULL,   model = NULL,   df = NULL,   x_col = NULL,   y_col = NULL )

title: Probability of Superiority Calculation — probability_superiority
text: d effect size m1 mean group one m2 mean group two sd1 standard deviation group one sd2 standard deviation group two n1 sample size group one n2 sample size group two significance level t optional, calculate d independent t, must include n1 n2 degrees freedom model optional, calculate d t.test independent t, must still include n1 n2 df optional dataframe includes x_col y_col x_col name column contains factor levels numeric vector group 1 scores y_col name column contains dependent score numeric vector group 2 scores

title: Probability of Superiority Calculation — probability_superiority
text: probability superiority.

title: Probability of Superiority Calculation — probability_superiority
text: provide one combination following: 1: d 2: m1 n2 3: t, n1, n2 4: model, n1, n2 5: df, "x_col", "y_col" 6: x_col, y_col numeric vectors

title: Probability of Superiority Calculation — probability_superiority

what: Proportion Overlap Calculations for Cohen's d — proportion_overlap
title: Proportion Overlap Calculations for Cohen's d — proportion_overlap
text: function calculates proportion overlap two independent group d effect size calculations. Cohen's u1, u2, u3 proportion overlap provided.

title: Proportion Overlap Calculations for Cohen's d — proportion_overlap
code: proportion_overlap(   model = NULL,   x_col = NULL,   y_col = NULL,   df = NULL,   d = NULL )

title: Proportion Overlap Calculations for Cohen's d — proportion_overlap
text: model saved independent t-test model x_col name column contains factor levels numeric vector group 1 scores y_col name column contains dependent score numeric vector group 2 scores df optional dataframe includes x_col y_col d previously calculated d value

title: Proportion Overlap Calculations for Cohen's d — proportion_overlap
text: list following: u1 Proportion non-overlap across distributions u2 Proportion one group proportion group u3 Proportion one group smaller median group p_o Proportional overlap distributions

title: Proportion Overlap Calculations for Cohen's d — proportion_overlap

what: Visualization for Estimating c Bias + Estimates — visualize_c_map

text: function displays visualization possible bias c allows non-zero effect sensitivity. function includes ability add values effect size correlation see map onto proposed c value.

title: Visualization for Estimating c Bias + Estimates — visualize_c_map
code: visualize_c_map(   dlow,   r_values,   d_values = NULL,   f_values = NULL,   f2_values = NULL,   nnt_values = NULL,   prob_values = NULL,   prop_u1_values = NULL,   prop_u2_values = NULL,   prop_u3_values = NULL,   prop_overlap_values = NULL,   point_colors = c("red", "green", "blue"),   size = 2,   shape_1 = 2,   shape_2 = 3,   ribbon_color = "lightblue",   lower = TRUE )

title: Visualization for Estimating c Bias + Estimates — visualize_c_map
text: dlow lower limit possible effect size (required). r_values vector correlation values possible (required). d_values vector effect size values possible. f_values vector f effect size values possible. f2_values vector f2 effect size values possible. nnt_values vector number needed treat effect size values possible. prob_values vector probability superiority effect size values possible. prop_u1_values vector proportion overlap u1 effect size values possible. prop_u2_values vector proportion overlap u2 effect size values possible. prop_u3_values vector proportion overlap u3 effect size values possible. prop_overlap_values vector proportion distribution overlap effect size values possible. point_colors vector color names codes plot effect sizes graph. use many color names/codes max effect size (.e, r 4, d 3, prob 5, use 5 max number colors). size size symbols chart. shape_1 numeric value one ggplot2 shapes shape_2 numeric value one ggplot2 shapes - use different numbers, two shapes overlaid, found effect made easier read many effect sizes plotted graph. ribbon_color color name code shade area shows non-zero effect sensitivity. lower Use indicate want lower upper bound d one sided confidence intervals. d positive, generally want lower = TRUE, negative d values enter lower = FALSE upper bound closer zero (required).

title: Visualization for Estimating c Bias + Estimates — visualize_c_map
text: Returns pretty graph possible effect size correlation combinations region effect colored . Note effect sizes converted d graph. graph graph possible values c

title: Visualization for Estimating c Bias + Estimates — visualize_c_map
code: visualize_c_map(dlow = .25,   d_values = c(.2, .3, .8),   r_values = c(.1, .4, .3),   lower = TRUE) #> $graph  #>
